p: Climate change is a growing public health threat; an emerging body of literature reports associations with infectious and noncommunicable disease, mental health, malnutrition, and mortality.1 In the field of infectious disease, extreme weather events caused by climate change, such as flooding and drought, have been linked to a higher frequency of vector-, water-, and food-borne diseases and fungal infections.1 Furthermore, extreme weather events can cause food insecurity, human migration, and infrastructure disruption, all of which can be associated with poor health outcomes.2
